metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: C++ Syntax
C++ Syntax
Let's break up the following code to understand it better:
content.html: Let's break up the following code to understand it better:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
#include <iostream>using namespace std;int main() {  
  cout << "Hello World!";  return 0;}

content.code:
#include <iostream>using namespace std;int main() {
cout << "Hello World!";  return 0;}

syntax_highlighting.text:
#include <iostream>using namespace std;int main() {  
  cout << "Hello World!";  return 0;}

content.code_html:
#include <iostream>
using namespace std;

int main() {
  cout << "Hello World!";
  return 0;
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
#include <iostream>using namespace std;int main() {  
  cout << "Hello World!";  return 0;}

content.text: Example explained
Line 1: #include <iostream> is a header file library that lets us work with input and output objects, such as cout (used in line 5). Header files add functionality to C++ programs.
content.html: Line 1: #include <iostream> is a header file library that lets us work with input and output objects, such as cout (used in line 5). Header files add functionality to C++ programs.

content.text: Line 2: using namespace std means that we can use names for objects and variables from the standard library.
content.html: Line 2: using namespace std means that we can use names for objects and variables from the standard library.

content.text: Don't worry if you don't understand how #include <iostream> and using namespace std works. Just think of it as something that (almost) always appears in your program.
content.html: Don't worry if you don't understand how #include <iostream> and using namespace std works. Just think of it as something that (almost) always appears in your program.

content.text: Line 3: A blank line. C++ ignores white space. But we use it to make the code more readable.
content.html: Line 3: A blank line. C++ ignores white space. But we use it to make the code more readable.

content.text: Line 4: Another thing that always appear in a C++ program is int main() . This is called a function . Any code inside its curly brackets {} will be executed.
content.html: Line 4: Another thing that always appear in a C++ program is int main(). This is called a function. Any code inside its curly brackets {} will be executed.

content.text: Line 5: cout (pronounced "see-out") is an object used together with the insertion operator ( << ) to output/print text. In our example, it will output "Hello World!".
content.html: Line 5: cout (pronounced "see-out") is an object used together with the insertion operator (<<) to output/print text. In our example, it will output "Hello World!".

content.text: Note: C++ is case-sensitive: "cout" and "Cout" has different meaning.
content.html: Note: C++ is case-sensitive: "cout" and "Cout" has different meaning.

content.text: Note: Every C++ statement ends with a semicolon ; .
content.html: Note: Every C++ statement ends with a semicolon ;.

content.text: Note: The body of int main() could also been written as: int main () { cout << "Hello World! "; return 0; }
content.html:
Note: The body of int main() could also been written as:
int main () { cout << "Hello World! "; return 0; }

content.text: Remember: The compiler ignores white spaces. However, multiple lines makes the code more readable.
content.html: Remember: The compiler ignores white spaces. However, multiple lines makes the code more readable.

content.text: Line 6: return 0; ends the main function.
Line 7: Do not forget to add the closing curly bracket } to actually end the main function.
content.html: Line 7: Do not forget to add the closing curly bracket } to actually end the main function.

content.text: Omitting Namespace

You might see some C++ programs that runs without the standard namespace library. The using namespace std line can be omitted and replaced with the std keyword, followed by the :: operator for some objects:
content.html: You might see some C++ programs that runs without the standard namespace library. The using namespace std line can be omitted and replaced with the std keyword, followed by the :: operator for some objects:

content.code_html:
#include <iostream>

int main() {
  std::cout << "Hello World!";
  return 0;
}

content.text: It is up to you if you want to include the standard namespace library or not.
content.html: It is up to you if you want to include the standard namespace library or not.

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
What is #include <iostream> ?

content.question: What is #include <iostream>?
